verses.text: O LORD, the king rejoices in Your strength; how greatly he exults in Your salvation!
verses.comment: The psalmist celebrates God's deliverance of the king. The word 'salvation' (Hebrew: 'yeshuah') is used here, with possible messianic overtones, as Christian tradition often reads this verse as pointing forward to Christ's victory (see Ps. 2:2).

verses.text: You have given him his heart’s desire and have not withheld the request of his lips. Selah.
verses.comment: This verse connects directly with Psalm 20:4; note the divine granting of requests is reminiscent of intercessory prayer and the value of persistent supplication.

verses.text: For You meet him with rich blessings; You set a crown of pure gold upon his head.
verses.comment: The crowning scene evokes messianic imagery; the pure gold crown points forward typologically to Christ the King, foreshadowed in David. This royal motif is echoed in Rev. 19:12.

verses.text: He asked life from You, and You gave it to him—length of days forever and ever.
verses.comment: The phrase 'forever and ever' (Hebrew: 'olam va'ed') goes beyond earthly kingship and prophetically anticipates the resurrection and eternal reign attributed to the Messiah (cf. Luke 1:33).

verses.text: His glory is great through Your salvation; You bestow splendor and majesty upon him.
verses.comment: Language of splendor and majesty closely matches the Old Testament’s high view of Davidic kingship, ultimately fulfilled in Christ’s glorification—see Philippians 2:9-11.

verses.text: For You make him most blessed forever; You make him glad with the joy of Your presence.
verses.comment: The joy of God’s presence prefigures the beatific vision promised in Catholic theology and ultimately realized in the heavenly kingdom (cf. Rev. 21:3-4).

verses.text: For the king trusts in the LORD, and through the steadfast love of the Most High he shall not be moved.
verses.comment: Trust in God’s 'steadfast love' (Hebrew: 'hesed') is a theme closely tied to the biblical covenants, and especially God’s faithfulness to the house of David.

verses.text: Your hand will find out all Your enemies; Your right hand will seize those who hate You.
verses.comment: The imagery of God’s 'right hand' is often associated with mighty acts of deliverance, echoing Exodus 15:6 and prefiguring Christ’s position at the Father’s right hand (Acts 2:33).

verses.text: You will make them like a blazing oven when You appear. The LORD will swallow them up in His wrath, and fire will devour them.
verses.comment: References to fire and judgment connect with themes of divine justice and eschatological reckoning, inviting meditation on the reality of final judgment (cf. Malachi 4:1; 2 Thess. 1:7-8).

verses.text: You will destroy their offspring from the earth, and their descendants from among the children of man.
verses.comment: Eradication of enemies’ descendants underscores God’s total victory—a foreshadowing of the triumph of Christ’s kingdom in the world.

verses.text: Though they plot evil against You and devise wicked schemes, they will not succeed.
verses.comment: The futility of scheming against God recalls the plotting of the nations against Christ in Psalm 2, fulfilled by the opposition to Jesus (Acts 4:25-28).

verses.text: For You will put them to flight; You will aim at their faces with Your bow.
verses.comment: The divine warrior imagery echoes other Old Testament texts and is spiritually understood as Christ conquering evil through the Paschal Mystery—His death and resurrection.

verses.text: Be exalted, O LORD, in Your strength! We will sing and praise Your power.
verses.comment: The psalm closes with praise to God, a liturgical action still central today. Catholic tradition, echoing Early Church practice, sees this as anticipating the eternal heavenly liturgy (Rev. 5:13)—where Christ is eternally exalted and worshipped by the Church.
